NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

Chad announced that soldiers from Niger are occupying islands on lake Chad, which are in Chad's territorial waters. Negotiations over ownership of the islands failed. First day of dispute was on 7/26/1995 and last day of dispute was on 7/00/1995.

RIVNOTES: 

NARRATIVE-CM:
Chadian police and Nigeria police clashed near the border on May 16, 1976, resulting in the deaths of three Nigerian policemen. Chad and Nigeria disputed the sovereignty *of several islands on Lake Chad in 1983. Chadian troops and Nigerian troops engaged in military hostilities beginning on April 18, 1983, resulting in the deaths of nine Nigerian soldiers and 75 Chadian soldiers. President Shehu Shagari of Nigeria and President Hissen Habre of Chad signed a ceasefire agreement in Abuja, Nigeria on July 2, 1983. The countries re-opened the border on May 15, 1984.

SOURCES-CM: 
*Africa Research Bulletin* (ARB), May 1-31, 1976, May 1-31, 1983, June 1-30, 1983, July 1-31, 1983; Allock et al., 1992, 234; Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997, 466-467.
